awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Halocarbon Biogeochemistry in Coastal Wetland Ecosystems - Exploring the Transition from Forested Wetland to Salt Marsh
awd_abstract_narration:
The relatively flat southeastern US coastal plain, from North Carolina to Texas, is particularly susceptible to sea level rise. As sea level rises, the boundary between the low-lying coastal freshwater forest and high marsh moves upslope. Highly productive forested wetlands are replaced successively by degraded wetlands and eventually by coastal salt marsh. Not only does saltwater intrusion change vegetation composition, high halide levels (called halogens) can interact with the large pool of soil organic matter through halogenation processes that are still poorly understood.  These halogenation processes are important to elucidate as they produce volatile halocarbons that act as ozone-depleting compounds in the atmosphere. Halogenation of organic matter may also affect the decomposition rates of organic matter. This interdisciplinary research will improve our understanding of chlorine and bromine biogeochemistry and demonstrate the importance of halogens in carbon cycling. This collaborative research represents a new collaboration between four investigators with different specialties from universities in the northeast, southeast and western United States. Graduate and undergraduate students will have opportunities to interact with citizen scientists in an on-going EarthWatch project and learn how to disseminate the scientific knowledge to the general public.  This study will also raise the awareness of the impacts of sea level rise on low-lying coastal areas in the Southeastern US.

Halogens have historically been treated as inert elements in natural humification processes.  However, numerous recent studies have demonstrated that chlorine and bromine are active components in C cycles. The overall goal of this research is to assess novel decomposition process routes of terrestrial organic matter in forested wetlands with high levels of chloride and bromide. The research project includes both field investigations and controlled experiments to determine the impacts of sea level rise on C and halogen biogeochemical cycles along salinity gradients in Winyah Bay, South Carolina.  Fluxes of halogenated ozone depleting C compounds and greenhouse gases, as well as concentrations of organochlorine and organobromine in soil and litter and water will be quantified along salinity transects and within controlled plots. The research team contends that the novel method of determining X-ray absorption near edge structures (XANES) of halogenated organic matter in soil and detritus layers, coupled with measurements of halocarbon emission and composition in water using Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry (FT-ICR MS), will be useful in understanding the roles of halogens in C cycling. Determining the seasonal variation of halocarbon in air, soil, and water from freshwater forested wetland, salt-degraded wetland, and salt marsh sites, representing the transition of coastal wetland under sea level rise, will be useful in developing a mechanistic and landscape understanding of how sea level rise affects decomposition, humification, and halogenation processes of terrestrial organic matter in coastal wetlands. The controlled field experiments using different concentrations of chloride and bromide waters would illustrate their roles in humification and decomposition processes.

por.por_cntn:
The relatively flat southeastern US coastal plain, from Texas to North Carolina, is particularly susceptible to sea level rise.  Rising sea level significantly changes soil and water salinity, vegetation composition, greenhouse gas emissions, and eventually the ecosystem functions of coastal ecosystems. As sea level rises, the boundary between the low-lying coastal forest and high marsh moves up slope. Forest vegetation is replaced successively by coastal salt marsh. Of particular interest are salt-impacted, degraded forested wetlands as they are the reactive mixing zones of terrestrial natural organic matter and seawater. High levels of chloride and bromide alter soil and water chemistry and microbial communities, resulting in a unique halocarbon biogeochemistry processes in this organic-rich and salty environment. One of the main environmental concerns about halocarbons is their high stratospheric ozone depletion potential and global warming potential. The goal of this collaborative research project was to study the consequences of sea level rise on carbon, chlorine, and bromine cycles and associated biogeochemical processes along this forest-marsh transition.

Intellectual Merits:

The research study integrated field investigations and controlled field experiments, coupled with X-ray absorption near edge structures (XANES) and Fourier Transform Ion Cyclotron Resonance Mass Spectrometry (FT-ICR-MS), to evaluate halocarbon emissions and organohalogen formation from decomposing terrestrial organic matter under different salinity regimes in Winyah Bay, South Carolina. Results confirmed that chloride and bromide from seawater intrusion altered terrestrial organic matter cycling in salt-impacted degraded wetlands. The salt-impacted degraded areas showed significant chloroform emission, and the flux was larger or comparable to reported fluxes from other natural ecosystems. On the other hand, methyl halide (i.e., CH3Cl and CH3Br) were the dominate halocarbon species in salt-marsh whereas chloroform dominated halocarbon species in salt-impacted degraded wetlands, illustrating there were different halogenation processes along the forest-marsh transition zones. A large repository of organobromine forms from the reactions of seawater with terrestrial natural organic matter was observed and the reactions were rapid, on the order of hours to days. The laboratory study showed bromide had a greater propensity than chloride in the decomposition and humification process. The formation mechanism of organohalogen may include abiotic process formation of reactive bromine and chlorine species. Our study documented for the first time on the halocarbon concentrations in air, soil, water along the forest-marsh transition zones induced by rising sea level.

Broader Impacts:

This success of this NSF project was a good example of interdisciplinary and collaborative research, involving three universities from different regions of the US (i.e., Clemson University, Princeton University, and University of California at Berkeley), two federal agencies (i.e., US Geological Survey and Pacific Northwest National Lab), one state agency (South Carolina Department of Natural Resources), and two non-profit organizations (i.e., the EarthWatch Institute and Hobcaw Barony). Not only did this collaborative effort provide analytical resources and field accesses to the scientific researchers, but also it offered cooperative and field-based learning experiences to undergraduate students as well as high school teachers and students.  Furthermore, our project helped to better understand litter degradation, carbon turnover, and formation of halocarbons and greenhouse gases along the freshwater forest-salt marsh transition zone on the Atlantic coast. This is of great importance as saltwater intrusion have impacted many coastal areas as a result of melting glaciers and polar ice caps. Moreover, quantification of the emissions of ozone-degrading halocarbons and greenhouse gases along the salinity transect helped not only to better understand the global budgets of these climate-relevant gases, but also to demonstrate how emissions might change as a result of global sea level rise. The die-back of forest in the forest-salt marsh transition zone has in what are now ghost forests. Results of the study raised awareness of the problems of the ghost forests and influences of sea level rise.  Because of the existing infrastructure and observations from this study, there are new research studies now examining different biogeochemical processes in the forest-marsh transition zone.
